body_html:
@yaroslavvb thanks for the suggestion. I finally settled down on avoiding the shape parameter in the sparse_placeholder as almost all examples I found did not specify the shape parameter for the sparse_placeholder.

I also traced it into the tensorflow python code, and found that the shape is converted to a int64 array, and the int64 dtype is hard-coded.
body_text:
@yaroslavvb thanks for the suggestion. I finally settled down on avoiding the shape parameter in the sparse_placeholder as almost all examples I found did not specify the shape parameter for the sparse_placeholder.
I also traced it into the tensorflow python code, and found that the shape is converted to a int64 array, and the int64 dtype is hard-coded.
body:
@yaroslavvb thanks for the suggestion. I finally settled down on avoiding the `shape` parameter in the `sparse_placeholder` as almost all examples I found did not specify the `shape` parameter for the `sparse_placeholder`. 

I also traced it into the tensorflow python code, and found that the `shape` is converted to a `int64` array, and the `int64` dtype is hard-coded.
